medicalLists.title: 5 Causes of Acute Liver Failure
medicalLists.rawContent:
1. Acetaminophen toxicity
2. Viral hepatitis (A, B, E)
3. Autoimmune hepatitis
4. Wilson's disease
5. Budd-Chiari syndrome

expectedCards.front: 45yo F with confusion, jaundice, and elevated LFTs. History of taking multiple Tylenol for headache over 3 days. Most likely diagnosis?
28yo M from endemic area presents with jaundice, fever, RUQ pain. Anti-HAV IgM positive. Diagnosis?
expectedCards.back: Acute hepatitis A causing acute liver failure

expectedCards.front: 35yo F with jaundice, ascites, confusion. Labs show elevated ANA, anti-smooth muscle antibodies. Diagnosis?
expectedCards.back: Autoimmune hepatitis with acute liver failure

expectedCards.front: 22yo M with psychiatric symptoms, jaundice, Kayser-Fleischer rings on slit lamp. Low ceruloplasmin. Diagnosis?
expectedCards.back: Wilson's disease presenting as acute liver failure

expectedCards.front: 40yo F with hepatomegaly, ascites, and severe RUQ pain. Doppler shows hepatic vein thrombosis. Diagnosis?
expectedCards.back: Budd-Chiari syndrome (hepatic vein thrombosis) causing acute liver failure

medicalLists.title: Causes of Hyponatremia by Volume Status
medicalLists.rawContent:
Hypovolemic: Diuretics, GI losses, third-spacing
Euvolemic: SIADH, hypothyroidism, psychogenic polydipsia
Hypervolemic: CHF, cirrhosis, nephrotic syndrome

expectedCards.front: 72yo M on furosemide presents with weakness, dizziness. Na 125, dry mucous membranes. Volume status and cause?
expectedCards.back: Hypovolemic hyponatremia due to diuretic use

expectedCards.front: 55yo M with small cell lung cancer, Na 122, euvolemic on exam. Urine osmolality inappropriately high. Diagnosis?
65yo F with CHF, bilateral leg edema, ascites. Na 128. Volume status and mechanism?
expectedCards.back: Hypervolemic hyponatremia due to CHF (excess total body water despite low effective arterial volume)

medicalLists.title: Cardiac Auscultation Findings
medicalLists.rawContent:
S3: Ventricular filling (CHF, dilated ventricle)
S4: Atrial contraction against stiff ventricle (HTN, AS)
Midsystolic click: Mitral valve prolapse
Opening snap: Mitral stenosis

expectedCards.front: 58yo M with dyspnea, JVD, extra heart sound after S2. Echo shows dilated LV. What sound and diagnosis?
expectedCards.back: S3 gallop indicating volume overload/CHF with reduced EF

expectedCards.front: 70yo F with long-standing HTN. Extra heart sound before S1, heard best at apex. Significance?
expectedCards.back: S4 gallop indicating stiff/hypertrophied LV from chronic HTN

expectedCards.front: 28yo F with palpitations. Mid-systolic click followed by late systolic murmur. Most likely diagnosis?
expectedCards.back: Mitral valve prolapse (midsystolic click is hallmark finding)

clinicalScenarios.presentation: 58yo M with sudden chest pain radiating to back, BP 180/110 in R arm, 130/85 in L arm
clinicalScenarios.diagnosis: Aortic dissection (Type A if ascending aorta)

clinicalScenarios.presentation: 45yo F with worst headache of life, sudden onset during exercise. CT shows hyperdensity in basal cisterns.
65yo M smoker with progressive dyspnea. PFTs show FEV1/FVC <0.7, no reversibility with bronchodilators.

overlappingCloze.title: HOCM Management Steps
overlappingCloze.content: Treatment for HOCM: {{c1::Avoid dehydration}} → {{c2::Beta-blockers or verapamil}} → {{c3::Consider septal reduction therapy}} if medical therapy fails

overlappingCloze.title: Acute Stroke Workup
overlappingCloze.content: Stroke protocol: {{c1::Non-contrast head CT}} → {{c2::Check time of symptom onset}} → {{c3::tPA if <4.5 hours}} and no contraindications → {{c4::Neurology consult}}
